instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
This board came in with some liquid spil near the Type C ports. Short to ground on <RESISTOR>R3350</RESISTOR>. Found a broken line under <DIODE>D3309</DIODE> and after fixing that short is gone. Also replaced <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> for a new one as this one showed a slightly higher temp in Flircam then the one besides it. <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> also was hot, replaced that for a new one. Now nothing on the board gets hot but still, 5.18v on the charger and 0.02A. No short one the below lines:

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.41
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = drops from 5V to 0 slowly
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> = 5.21v

Any ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: I replaced one, let me try the other one as well, good point :).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: Be sure to use the correct termination!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: Hello 2informatics, what do you mean by that?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Replaced the 2 CD3215C's but no luck yet. I have following measurements:

F3000 & F3010 = 5.21v, should this not be 20v?
<CHIP>U2890</CHIP> had some dirt around it so i replaced it, but no 20v yet

Edit: the CD3215C's i used i bought from China. I just read somewhere, these IC are programmed? Im not sure if these IC are new, they look like they have been reballed. Just to make sure, will use the CD3215s from a donor board instead and try that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: Did you use the right firmware? C00 and B03 are different chips that?s what 2informaticos meant

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
"<CHIP>U2890</CHIP> had some dirt around it so i replaced it"
That is USB ROM; must be from same model board!!!
But usually suffers by corroded resistors, or traces; chip should be good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> I took from the same board yep 840. Unfortunately customer had to leave and picked up the Mac, might be back tomorrow if he has more time. [USER="137"]john[/USER], I used the IC with exact same number on them yes.
